The intelligibility of the new geometries
6. The intelligibility of the new geometries

The epistemological significance of projective geometry rests on its
implications for the nature and rigour of classical geometry. The
epistemological significance of non-Euclidean geometry rests more on
the possibility that it could be true in whatever way that Euclidean
geometry could be true. We therefore turn to 19th century
examinations of the intelligibility of geometry.

But first a word of warning. The logical fact that non-Euclidean
geometry turned out to be consistent (relative to Euclidean geometry,
or to real analysis) does not per se establish the invalidity of the
Kantian viewpoint. Kant's views are compatible with the existence of
logical alternatives to Euclidean geometry; after all, he was arguing
about space as an intuition, not about mere conceptual possibilities;
he was not a Leibnizian, and denied that geometry is analytic. If
anything, a Kantian would expect that the alternative geometries are
only an intellectual possibility, and that we cannot visualize them
intuitively. A sophisticated elaboration of such a standpoint was
Frege's in his famous correspondence with Hilbert (see the entry on the
 Frege-Hilbert controversy).
 But it's true that most of the relevant authors chose a different
line of thought and abandoned the Kantian position.
